title: Final Cut Pro X 10.4.4 Demo - Noise Reduction, Caption Burn In, and More
tags: how to remove noise from video
description: Final Cut Pro X 10.4.4 introduces new features, such as: video noise reduction, a Comparison Viewer, caption burn ins, and much more!  Watch Vintage Apple Vault   Watch Krazy Ken's Tech Misadventures   Dont miss future tech videos!    Like the CC on Facebook   Follow the CC on Twitter   Follow Ken on Twitter: @Hildron101010  Need more Final Cut help? I would love to train you! Get 1-on-1 Final Cut training    Final Cut Pro X release notes   Legacy media document   Learn more about FCP X captions    Contact the CC    Want music for your videos?   (We use these guys a lot. They're good.)  Get film gear Ken uses   On a lower budget?   Amazon links are powered by the Amazon Associates Program.
transcript: - [Ken] Today on TidBytes, I wanna show you the new features in Final Cut Pro 10.4.4. Let's take a look. Hey, how's it going? I'm Ken from the Computer Clan, and Final Cut Pro 10.4.4 is out, and best of all, it is a free upgrade for existing Final Cut Pro users. So if the upgrade hasn't come through automatically through the app store, check your updates. It should be there for you, free update. So inside of Final Cut Pro, if you go to the help menu and click on what's new, you'll see there's some great new features. And I will go into much more later, and I also have another thing that Apple announced that I do wanna share with you, and I'll share that near the end. But for now, let's just dive into some demos. One of the new things is extensions. Now, Final Cut Pro has had plugin support for a long time. There's actually a huge ecosystem of Final Cut Pro plugins out there, but now Apple has a first party colation solution for this. It's their own gallery of plugins. You can access them right inside of Final Cut Pro. You can get them right from the Mac app store and summon them with this little button in your toolbar. So if you want things like Shutterstock or Frame.io accessible right inside of Final Cut Pro, you can now do that with 10.4.4. Now, I'm not sure if this is working for everybody yet. It is brand new at the time I am making this demo, because every time I click the get button, nothing happens. But if it works for you, great. There's only a few things available right now, but there's more coming. For the first new feature I wanna show, I wanna go to the window menu, go to show in workspace, and open the new comparison viewer. So let's say I want to color grade this clip. I may want to see what it looks like ungraded next to a view of what it looks like after grading. So in the comparison viewer here, I like to use the saved tab on top, and then I can click on saved frame. So let's say I want this part of this Vintage Apple Vault episode that I've been shooting. I wanna color correct this and grade it. Right here where my finger is, I wanna save that, and now that will show up in my comparison viewer. In fact, I can save up to 30 frames and switch between them in the frame browser. So if I want a different frame of this episode, I can save frame, and inside the frame browser, I can simply switch between the two. So let's go back to that shot of the G4 Cube and let's do some color adjustments. So shortcut Command-6 to get to my color corrections. Push those highlights. Crush the blacks here. So now instead of always going on and off, and on and off to see my corrections, I can just look at the graded clip next to the ungraded clip right here inside of the new comparison viewer. Next I'm gonna show the floating time code window, so I'm going to turn off the comparison viewer, go back to the window menu, and choose source timecode. So what this will do is it will show me the project time code on top in white, and then it will give me sources. So down here I have an A-roll shot of me talking, and then I have a B-roll shot of this G4 Cube. And as you can see, I have the A-roll shot time code here, the B-roll shot time code here, the project time code on the top, and this music track on the bottom. And as I scrub, you will see all of the time codes adjust. And with this little arrow in the upper right, I can choose what information I want displayed, and what information I want hidden. And I can even make the background semi-transparent if I want to. Another cool thing is I can do batch exporting of projects and clips from the browser. Shift-F is the shortcut to find a timeline item inside the browser. So if I want to batch share a bunch of clips, let's say I need to roundtrip them with another program, I can command click the three that I want, go to file, share three clips, and I can export with any of my presets. I can also send the clips to compressor. The marquee selection in the timeline has also been updated. So let's say I have these clips in a secondary storyline. Normally if I did a marquee selection, this would always happen. I would individually select the clips inside of the storyline. I could never actually select the entire storyline with the marquee, but now I can. If I drag the marquee around the gray part of the storyline, I can select the whole thing with the marquee selection. Let's look at the comic effect. I'm gonna go to the effects browser, type in comic. This is a new effect in here. I'm gonna drag that on. So what it will do is it will take live action footage and give it a comic look, and there's a lot of ways I can mess with this but my favorite way to use this is with the black and white mode and I like to shrink the ink edges down to be really small. So now we can kinda have a comic book look going on here. Alright, now we're looking really pop arty. So the comic effects are now new, built into Final Cut Pro 10.4.4. Let's look at video noise reduction. So I was shooting a film in an abandoned theater, and as you could imagine, it's pretty darn dark. And just for the sake of the demo, I'm really gonna push the highlights up. I'm gonna push them to a point probably where I shouldn't push them, because now, if we zoom in here; this is 4K footage, but if we zoom in here, you're gonna see we're gonna get a lot of noise now. I can work with this low light footage and reduce the noise. I'm gonna drop the noise reduction effect on here and watch what it does. You sit for a little bit, and then there's the result. It smoothed out some of the noise. And I'm just gonna warn you ahead of time. This process can really take a long time to render, especially on an older computer. Now, my computer at this time is five years old so it's a little bit slow with this kind of stuff. Newer computers might be fine. But just be warned, noise reduction can be kinda sluggish. In the inspector here, I can adjust how much noise reduction I want applied, and I can adjust how much sharpening is added after the effect is processed. This if I turn the effect off, you see a lot of that noise. Turn it on, it's kinda softening that noise now. I'll scrub around, find a different sample. It'll start processing again. There we go. And let's say I go to maximum. It'll reprocess. So that's maximum noise reduction, that's medium noise reduction, and that's no noise reduction. So now if I had to continue grading this and crush some of those blacks, it might not look too shabby. It's a little soft, but I can always go back and go medium and then add in a little bit of sharpness. And now it's not as bad. It's still ideal to shoot it right from the beginning, but if we look at the before and after, you can see we cranked up the light and we didn't introduce a lot of noise. Now let's take a look at another fun tech show that I do, Krazy Ken's Tech Misadventures. And coincidentally, the episode we're looking at today is about video editing. Not in Final Cut Pro, but in Adobe Premiere 1.0. Wow. Times have really changed. Final Cut Pro a little while ago introduced the ability to do captions, but there's a couple differences now. So I have a caption track in here, as you can see, with all this purple on top. And one of the new features is SRT editing and exporting. So this is actually an SRT file that I'm working with. It's not an ITT file. It's not an SCC file. It's SRT, which is pretty standard for social media. But it doesn't just stop there. Yes, the SRT support is new, but when I go to export, here's something else I can do. Under the rolls, down here is normally where I could export my caption file. But with this option here, I can actually burn the captions into the video. So with the captions burned into the video, that means all of this text right here will be permanently inside the video burned in. Pixel for pixel it will always appear during video playback. And rest assured, if the text looks a little pixelated inside of Final Cut, don't worry. It is smoothed out in antialiased on export, and it looks much better. So there's some other great features built in to this new version of Final Cut Pro, such as tiny planet mapping for 360 footage, and there's new 360 transitions, such as a gaussian blur and a bloom. In fact, in the description, I have a link to the release notes, and you can see all of the details that Apple outlined. As you can see, there's quite a bit to go through, so feel free to go to the description, click that link and check that out. And this other bit is also pretty important. I did get an error message that popped up when I upgraded my libraries for this new version of Final Cut Pro. Certain formats and codecs are not gonna be supported anymore in a future version of Mac OS. So Apple has the support document that kinda outlines it for you. I wish Final Cut Pro would actually report what content in your current projects wouldn't be compatible in the future, but apparently it does not do that. And this link here will also give you a full list of supported media formats. So that's a quick look at Final Cut Pro 10.4.4. If you have any questions, let me know in the comments down below. And if you wanna check out some of the shows that I'm editing inside of Final Cut Pro, such as Vintage Apple Vault and Krazy Ken's Tech Misadventures, please check the links in the description. Those are some pretty fun videos to watch. Thanks for watching. I hope you learned something, and I'll see you in the not too distant future.
